author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Feeling Mortgage-Rate Envy? You’re Not Alone.
description: With interest rates climbing, a new form of one-upmanship is making the rounds: the mortgage-rate humble brag.
content: At a rooftop party on a steamy July night in Philadelphia, the margarita machine was churning, the seafood boil was hearty, and the conversation turned to the default of the upwardly mobile: real estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: U.S. Extends Job Growth Streak Even as Economy Cools
description: Employers added 187,000 workers in July, a slower pace than the recent norm, but “more sustainable,” one economist said.
content: The U.S. economy continued to generate sturdy employment growth in July, but it showed definite signs of cooling alongside the Federal Reserve’s battle to suppress inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Nelson Limerick
title: How One Adman Created the American Fantasy of Paul Bunyan
description: In W.B. Laughead’s 1916 logging industry pamphlet, a minor Midwestern folk hero underwent a major growth spurt.
content: Before there was fake news, there were tall tales. Often associated with the history of westward expansion, most of these tales carried expiration dates, their relevance fading in a dramatically changed world. But others turned out to have staying power as implausible as the mythic characters they celebrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
title: Michigan Republicans Charged in False Elector Scheme Appear in Court
description: The hearing in state court came in the same week that former President Donald J. Trump pleaded not guilty to federal charges connected to efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
content: Two Michigan Republicans charged with purporting to be electors for President Donald J. Trump in 2020 appeared before a state judge on Friday, adding to a flurry of court action this week tied to efforts to overturn the last presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Crime Is Down. So Why Don’t New Yorkers Feel Safe?
description: Crime isn’t what it was in the 1980s. But a new podcast about the Bernhard Goetz subway shootings suggests that even then, the fear of crime outpaced reality.
content: On Monday, Eric Adams announced a plan to combat gun violence in New York City, committing $485 million to a slate of initiatives largely aimed at prevention — more job training and expanded mental health care among others. It would focus on six precincts in the Bronx and Brooklyn, where nearly a quarter of the city’s shootings last year took place, a seemingly wise, data-driven use of resources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Apple’s and Amazon’s Report Cards for the Global Economy
description: The companies’ latest earnings reports provide insight into the state of consumers and businesses, including where they’re willing to spend — and cut costs.
content: Earnings reports yesterday from Apple and Amazon covered some very different businesses: premium-priced smartphones and tablets versus the world’s “everything store” and a dominant cloud computing platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Madison Malone Kircher
title: A Mystery on the ‘Planet of the Bass’
description: Is the ’90s Eurodance parody an ironic hit — or just a hit?
content: Get ready for blast off: We’re going to the Planet of the Bass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Back to the Future’ Review: The DeLorean Crash Lands on Broadway
description: The addition of 17 songs turns the 1985 sci-fi classic into a big “why?” musical with a big wow factor.
content: The brand-extension musical is a tough genre to game, demanding something new for newcomers yet fidelity for fans. (“Hairspray” succeeded; “Frozen” did not.) “Back to the Future: The Musical,” based on the first of the time-travel films in the billion-dollar franchise, faces an additional hurdle: It hinges on a star performance that would seem to be irreproducible onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Parkland Hosts a Grim Re-Enactment of a School Massacre
description: Ballistics experts and technicians reconstructed the 2018 school shooting, gunshot by gunshot, for use as possible evidence in a civil trial against a sheriff’s deputy.
content: The stillness felt eerie on Friday outside Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. Roads were closed. News crews waited across the street. A police helicopter thrummed overhead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and William K. Rashbaum
title: New Commissioner Forces at Least Four Top Cops to Retire From N.Y.P.D.
description: The resignations include Chief James Essig, the head of detectives, and Chief Kim Royster, who headed transportation.
content: At least four high-ranking New York Police Department officials, all with decades of experience, have been told to retire immediately, according to a senior official and a retired official with knowledge of the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Appeals Court Allows Biden’s Asylum Restrictions to Continue for Now
description: A federal judge had struck down the policy last week, but his ruling had not yet taken effect.
content: A federal appeals court said on Thursday that the Biden administration could continue enforcing its tough asylum policy on the southern border for at least several more weeks, while government lawyers appeal a judge’s order striking it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 11 Easy Vegetarian Summer Dinners
description: Bountiful meals for the most bountiful time of year.
content: After those excursions to the beach, leisurely park meet-ups and daylong pool hangs, you’ve still got to eat. Chances are you’re a bit wiped from the sun, too. So turn to the best produce summer has to offer and keep things as easy and breezy as the season. The recipes below come together in 30 minutes or less and make the most of the tomatoes, corn, eggplant, zucchini, green beans and cucumbers that we just can’t get enough of right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Hans
title: L.G.B.T.Q. Teens on ‘Heartstopper’: ‘I’m Fine With It Not Being Perfect’
description: Three British 16-year-olds took an advance look at Season 2. There was popcorn, giggling and more than a little eye-rolling.
content: This week, the British coming-of-age drama “Heartstopper” returned to laptop screens all over the world. Based on Alice Oseman’s webcomics, the Netflix series follows a romantic relationship between two high school students, Charlie (Joe Locke) and Nick (Kit Connor), whose friendship group includes a young trans woman, Elle (Yasmin Finney), and a lesbian couple, Tara (Corinna Brown) and Darcy (Kizzy Edgell).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Mitski’s Beautifully Moody Meditation, and 11 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Jorja Smith, Towa Bird, Wilco and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Nicholas Fandos and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Left-Leaning Democrats Meet in Secret to Find a Challenger to Eric Adams
description: A group of progressives held an early strategy meeting on Staten Island to discuss how they might defeat Mr. Adams in 2025. It won’t be easy.
content: On a warm July evening, as Mayor Eric Adams visited Staten Island to highlight his work on public safety at a town-hall meeting, a cross section of some of New York City’s progressive class was nearby, plotting how to make the mayor’s first term his last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: While Navigating Life’s Changes, a Teenage Romance Endures
description: Neither Olivia Amitrano nor Nicholas Vazquez are afraid to change their minds, whether it’s about living off the grid, work or a wedding dress.
content: Olivia Grace Amitrano and Nicholas Ryan Vazquez were only teenagers when they met. Still, they somehow had the sense to take it slow, which allowed their relationship to go the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy and Shelby Knowles
title: Amid the Mountains, They Can Be ‘Open Without Being Judged’
description: A four-day summer camp in Colorado promotes body positivity and empowerment through theater.
content: In a cabin in the Rocky Mountains, a murmur began to build like the jungle cacophony it was intended to mimic. It was the final afternoon of the four-day Camp Realize Your Beauty, and the nine campers were repeating the social media and popular culture messages about perfection that they felt bombarded by in their daily lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: From Portugal to Portland
description: Oregon decriminalized all drugs, and overdoses have surged.
content: When Oregon was getting ready to vote on whether to decriminalize all drugs in 2020, I was covering the story for Vox. During my interviews with the leaders of the decriminalization campaign, they often cited Portugal. It decriminalized all drugs in 2000. In the years after, Portugal’s drug-related problems declined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: For the First Time, There’s a Pill for Postpartum Depression
description: Because the pill works faster than other antidepressants and is taken for only two weeks, it may encourage more treatment of the debilitating condition.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first pill for postpartum depression, a milestone considered likely to increase recognition and treatment of a debilitating condition that afflicts about a half-million women in the United States every year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Valeriya Safronova
title: Jailed Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Receives New Sentence of 19 Years
description: Aleksei A. Navalny, who is already in prison, was sentenced for supporting “extremism,” amid intensified suppression of dissent in Russia.
content: A Russian court on Friday handed Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed opposition campaigner, a new, 19-year sentence on charges of supporting “extremism” and ordered him imprisoned under the harshest conditions. The sentence demonstrated the widening scope of repression under President Vladimir V. Putin and threatened to further isolate his most cutting domestic critic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elamin Abdelmahmoud
title: From Taylor Swift to Beyoncé, Concerts Are Turning Into Something New
description: Yes, the cost of concert tickets is exceptionally high. But for spectacle-starved fans, the memories are priceless.
content: I have found myself crying in public multiple times this summer, standing next to strangers who were also crying in public. I do not mean to suggest we were welling up or misty-eyed or otherwise feeling our feelings with some kind of dignity. We were not. We were properly crying, the sniffling and sobbing type, absolutely overwhelmed with joy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Families Confront Synagogue Shooter at His Sentencing
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 4, 2023.
content: “He murdered a 97-year-old great-grandmother, but he did not get us all.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Does Anyone Care About Justin Trudeau’s Separation?
description: A stable marriage (publicly at least) used to be a cornerstone of any world leader’s résumé. Not in 2023.
content: Like many public statements on the disintegration of a high-profile split these days, this one appeared on Instagram. “After many meaningful and difficult conversations,” a joint post said, Justin Trudeau, the prime minister of Canada, had separated from his wife, Sophie Grégoire Trudeau. The couple, who have three children and have been married for 18 years, were once seen to have had a fairy tale romance. But while the story was soon dominating headlines, millions also gave a digital shrug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Mike Pence Has Reached His Fork in the Road
description: The former vice president and Jan. 6 witness is campaigning to persuade voters. But is he also trying to warn them?
content: Through four years as Donald J. Trump’s vice president, or perhaps three years and 350 days, Mike Pence brandished a peerless talent: insisting that all was going smoothly amid plain evidence to the contrary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Marion Lozano
title: Superconductor Superconfusion, KOSA’s Hidden Costs and HatGPT
description: The only thing harder than making a room temperature superconductor may be passing internet regulation.
content: Researchers in Korea claim they’ve identified a material that could unlock a technological revolution: the room temperature superconductor. Material scientists are skeptical, but enthusiasts on Twitter are enthusiastic. Why is the internet so excited about superconductors?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: A Rising Tide Lifts Many Boats, but So Far Not Biden’s
description: The president is experiencing a flurry of good news on the economy, crime, immigration and other areas, but voters so far have not given the president much credit.
content: Inflation at long last is down. So are gas prices and Covid deaths and violent crime and illegal immigration. Unemployment remains near record lows. The economy, meanwhile, is growing, wages are climbing, consumer confidence is rising and the stock market is surging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: A Republican 2024 Climate Strategy: More Drilling, Less Clean Energy
description: Project 2025, a conservative “battle plan” for the next Republican president, would stop attempts to cut the pollution that is heating the planet and encourage more emissions.
content: During a summer of scorching heat that has broken records and forced Americans to confront the reality of climate change, conservatives are laying the groundwork for future  Republican administration that would dismantle efforts to slow global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis and Isabella Kwai
title: Acropolis Will Limit Visitor Numbers as Europe Tackles a Tourist Crush
description: Greece is trying to curb overcrowding and prevent damage at its most popular archaeological site. Other European destinations are also cracking down.
content: Greece will start capping the number of visitors to the Acropolis, government officials said, an effort to curb overcrowding at its most popular archaeological site amid wider worries about the impact of tourists thronging European attractions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Christiaan Triebert
title: Ukraine Hits a Distant Russian Ship, Showing Reach of Naval Drones
description: The attack damaged the warship hundreds of miles from Ukrainian-held territory, as Kyiv increasingly tries to bring the war home to Russia.
content: A Ukrainian maritime drone damaged a Russian warship on the Black Sea on Friday, the most serious strike on Moscow’s navy since last year, demonstrating both the escalating conflict at sea and the growing range and capability of Ukraine’s uncrewed vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Carlos Prieto, Will Reid, Mike Benoist, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Fighting Canada’s Unending Fires
description: Inside the largest wildfires in the country’s modern history — and how climate change has affected its ability to deal with them.
content: The wildfires sweeping Canada have become the largest in its modern history. Across the country, 30 million acres of forest have burned — three times as much land as in the worst American fire in the past 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Eagles’ Josh Sills Acquitted on Rape and Kidnapping Charges
description: Sills, 25, a Philadelphia Eagles offensive lineman, was indicted in Ohio in February.
content: A Philadelphia Eagles offensive lineman who was accused of rape and kidnapping was found not guilty on Friday by a jury in Guernsey County, Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Wesley Parnell
title: YouTube Streamer Faces Riot Charge After Union Square Park Erupts in Chaos
description: Thousands of people descended on the Manhattan park after Kai Cenat, a popular YouTube and Twitch streamer, promised to hand out free game consoles.
content: A popular social media streamer faced a charge of inciting a riot on Friday when an event at Manhattan’s Union Square Park where he planned to give away video game consoles descended into mayhem, drawing a crowd estimated at several thousand young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Jan Frodeno Begins His Triathlon Farewell Tour. Up Next? More Risky Sports.
description: Frodeno, 41, has dominating the triathlon since winning Olympic gold in 2008. This will be his last competitive season.
content: The end of an athletic career arrives for everyone, even Jan Frodeno, who is widely recognized as the greatest male triathlete ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Where ‘No One Wanted Girls,’ a Dad in India Takes On the Patriarchy
description: A delivery room epiphany transformed a village headman into an unlikely and highly successful campaigner against prenatal sex testing, which often led to aborting female fetuses.
content: When the nurse stepped out of the delivery room, her face turned somber as she approached with a baby in her arms wrapped in a blanket. Her voice dropped to a hush, almost like she was ashamed, as she announced to the family: “It is a daughter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: 3 Factors Keeping Americans From New Weight-Loss Drugs
description: A survey showed that many Americans were interested in obesity treatments like Wegovy but lost interest when confronted with the price and other factors.
content: A national survey released on Friday by KFF, a nonprofit organization focused on health policy, has found that Americans long for safe and effective drugs for weight loss. But the more they learn about new drugs like Wegovy that are transforming obesity treatment, the more their enthusiasm fades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Trump Indictment Presents New Obstacle in Spending Fight as Shutdown Looms
description: The far right is pushing to cut funding for the F.B.I. and the Justice Department, another complication for Speaker Kevin McCarthy as he seeks to avoid a government shutdown.
content: The political furor over the indictment this week of former President Donald J. Trump over his efforts to overturn the 2020 election is spilling into the escalating congressional spending fight as conservatives, following the former president’s lead, take aim at federal law enforcement agencies, raising yet another obstacle to avoiding a government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Istiaq Mian
title: Would Marrying Her Be a Giant Mistake?
description: I was warned not to marry outside my faith, but when Jillian was asleep in my bed, I would cry, unable to imagine a world without her.
content: I am Muslim. My potential father-in-law, Bob, is an evangelical Christian. I wanted to spend the rest of my life with his daughter, Jillian, but Bob had some serious concerns about that plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: India’s Top Court Clears Way for Rahul Gandhi’s Return to Parliament
description: India’s main opposition leader was kicked out of the legislature after a defamation case that his allies called politically motivated. He can also now run in next year’s elections.
content: India’s Supreme Court cleared the way on Friday for Rahul Gandhi, the country’s foremost opposition leader, to return to Parliament and run in next spring’s national elections, a contest that will pit Prime Minister Narendra Modi against a coalition featuring a debilitated Congress Party led unofficially by Mr. Gandhi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: Dinosaurs, androids, darkness and superheroes factor into this months sci-fi picks.
content: Anthology movies are, for the most part, wildly uneven, so it is worth noting how consistently good these five shorts are, despite being very different from each other. (All have been available to stream for free on YouTube but this new collection gathers them all under one convenient roof.) The umbrella title suggests we’re in for stories about the end of the world but only the Brazilian director Gabriel Kalim Mucci’s “Lunatique” fully fits that description. Wordless and depressingly evocative, the film follows a woman (Lila Guimarães) trying to survive in a blasted city. Mucci uses a monochromatic palette to create nightmarish tableaux, with haunting details here and there (I won’t soon forget that ferret). His film leaves you wanting a lot more, and when do viewers ever feel that way?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 9: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 11 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 22.
content: Welcome to Week Nine of our 14th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Mark Margolis, Scene-Stealing Actor in ‘Breaking Bad,’ Dies at 83
description: His character, an ex-drug lord in a wheelchair, was unable to speak, but Mr. Margolis, who also appeared in “Better Call Saul,” didn’t need dialogue to wield fearsome power.
content: Mark Margolis, the prolific actor whose simmering air of menace as the fearsome former drug lord Hector Salamanca in “Breaking Bad” transformed the innocent ding of a bellhop bell into a harbinger of doom, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Thanks to Carol Burnett and Dolly Parton, New Life for a 1988 Film
description: “Tokyo Pop,” starring Carrie Hamilton, a daughter of the comedian, was a critical hit that had fallen into obscurity and has now been restored.
content: When “Tokyo Pop” opened in April 1988, critics were upbeat, at least about its lead actress, Carrie Hamilton, a newcomer to movies who had appeared on TV’s “Fame.” The Los Angeles Times critic Sheila Benson wrote that Hamilton stalked through the film “straight into our hearts.” In The New York Times, Walter Goodman praised the movie, about an aspiring American pop star in Japan, for its “rhythm and zing.” The opening titles were designed by the artist Keith Haring at the height of his fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: William H. Dilday Jr., First Black TV Station Manager in U.S., Dies at 85
description: Hired to run a troubled Mississippi affiliate of NBC, he turned it into a respected and highly profitable operation, with a more diverse staff.
content: William H. Dilday Jr., a Boston TV executive who moved to Jackson, Miss., in 1972 to manage the city’s NBC affiliate, becoming the country’s first Black person to run a commercial television station, died on July 27 in Newton, Mass. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ann Patchett on Summer Love and Her New Novel
description: The author discusses “Tom Lake,” bookstore secrets and the play “Our Town.”
content: Ann Patchett’s new novel, “Tom Lake,” is set in northern Michigan during the early days of pandemic lockdown, and centers on a mother telling her grown daughters about the summer fling she had in her youth with an actor who went on to become a big star. Reviewing it in The Times (mostly favorably), Alexandra Jacobs noted that “Tom Lake” is a “resolutely folksy, cozy” novel, and on this week’s podcast Patchett tells the host Gilbert Cruz that that’s exactly how she wanted it — even though she knows some readers are skeptical of happy books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Richard Silvestri comes in hot with a difficult puzzle.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — This is Richard Silvestri’s 50th cryptic crossword for The New York Times, and I hope you’re up for a challenge! I usually expect a major obstacle here or there in a cryptic, not a cliff face that offers one toehold at a time. I actually solved the whole puzzle bottom to top, after feeling a real frisson of panic when I approached the clue set and found absolutely nothing to go on. Even in retrospect, the puzzle is marvelously tough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Oklahoma Man Pleads Guilty to Threatening DeSantis, Cruz and Other Republicans
description: Tyler Jay Marshall, 37, threatened on social media to shoot a number of Republican politicians. He faces up to five years in prison.
content: An Oklahoma man pleaded guilty on Wednesday to making death threats on social media against Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, Texas Senator Ted Cruz and other high-profile Republican politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Anna Netrebko Sues Met Opera After Losing Work Over Support of Putin
description: Seeking at least $360,000, the singer accused the storied opera house of discrimination, defamation and breach of contract. The company disputed her claims.
content: The star Russian soprano Anna Netrebko filed a lawsuit on Friday against the Metropolitan Opera, seeking at least $360,000 in compensation for work she lost when the company parted ways with her after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Is Trump Leaving an Opening in Iowa?
description: The former president’s poll numbers are still strong. But the caucuses could be his rivals’ best chance to make him look vulnerable.
content: Donald J. Trump has dominated the Republican Party for eight years, and our recent poll results show that he is dominating the Republican primary race again. So it’s not wrong to wonder whether Mr. Trump is simply undefeatable — even after his third criminal indictment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Most Frightening Part of the Trump Indictment
description: The former president’s attempt to overthrow our institutions would not have been possible without those institutions themselves.
content: Buried in the federal indictment of Donald Trump on four counts tied to his attempt to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election is one of the most chilling paragraphs ever written about the plans and intentions of an American president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and John Liu
title: The Chip Titan Whose Life’s Work Is at the Center of a Tech Cold War
description: At 92, Morris Chang, the founder of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, can no longer stay in the shadows.
content: In a wood-paneled office overlooking Taipei and the jungle-covered mountains that surround the Taiwanese capital, Morris Chang recently pulled out an old book stamped with technicolor patterns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Unsettled Debate at the Heart of the Henrietta Lacks Case
description: Do we own our bodies? The answer, according to many legal experts, is no.
content: Do we own our bodies? To an ordinary person, the answer is obviously yes. To a lawyer, it’s not at all clear. That discrepancy needs to be resolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: ‘Winning Time’ Is Back. Here’s What to Know Ahead of Season 2
description: Season 1 of HBO’s series about the 1980s Lakers came with drama, in more ways than one. Expect more for Season 2. An N.B.A. reporter takes a look.
content: Fictionalized shows drawn from real life don’t always satisfy the people depicted. But when the subjects are superstars accustomed to speaking for themselves, their criticism can take on a life of its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Matei Barbulescu
title: Andrew Tate Is Released From House Arrest in Romania
description: The online influencer and his brother, Tristan Tate, must remain in the country while they await trial on charges of human trafficking, a court in Bucharest ruled.
content: The online influencer Andrew Tate and his brother were released from house arrest in Romania on Friday but must remain in the country while they await trial on charges of human trafficking, after an order from a court in Bucharest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Remy Tumin
title: Leah Remini, Vocal Scientology Critic, Files Suit Against Church
description: The lawsuit, which alleges a pattern of harassment and defamation, is a culmination of a decade of criticism of Scientology by Ms. Remini, an actress, since she broke publicly with the church.
content: The actress Leah Remini, a former longtime member of the Church of Scientology who has been highly critical of the organization since leaving it in 2013, filed suit against the church this week seeking to end what she said were the “mob-style tactics” it had used to harass and defame her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Was It a Job Interview or a Date? She Soon Found Out.
description: Ashutosh Upreti asked Katherine Maher out for drinks after they met at a friend’s Seder. At first, she mistakenly thought their get-together was for a job and began interviewing him.
content: After exchanging a few pleasantries, Katherine Roberts Maher and Ashutosh Upreti got down to business over drinks in April 2019 at the now-shuttered Bond Bar in San Francisco’s Mission District.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Hip-Hop, 50 Years Later: Still a Love Language
description: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of hip-hop, The New York Times asked the poet Mahogany L. Browne to write an ode to the genre using only lyrics.
content: This year marks the 50th anniversary of hip-hop, a genre of music that experiments, rebels and defies any single definition. To mark the occasion, the Newsroom Projects and Initiatives team at The New York Times asked Mahogany L. Browne, an author and the first-ever poet-in-residence at Lincoln Center, to write a love letter celebrating hip-hop’s long-lasting effect on culture and music.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 4, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 4, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about former President Donald J. Trump’s scheduled appearance at a U.S. federal courthouse for election charges incorrectly stated the circumstances of Magistrate Judge Moxila A. Upadhyaya’s appointment. She was appointed by other judges, not by President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Australians’ ‘Golden Ticket’ to the U.S.
description: Proposed changes to the E-3 visa have worried some expatriates.
content: When Mete Erdogan, 35, first visited New York City as a tourist more than 10 years ago, he was stunned by the number of fellow Australians who seemed to be thriving there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dianna Wray and Javier C. Hernández
title: Opera Star David Daniels Pleads Guilty to Sexual Assault
description: The countertenor and his husband, Scott Walters, pleaded guilty to sexually assaulting a young singer in Houston in 2010, in a deal that will spare them jail time.
content: The opera star David Daniels, one of the world’s leading countertenors, pleaded guilty on Friday in Houston to sexually assaulting a young singer who had attended one of his performances there in 2010.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Lisa Lerer
title: DeSantis Dismisses Trump’s 2020 Election Theories as False
description: The Florida governor went further than he has before in acknowledging that the election was not stolen as a major donor pressured him to appeal to moderates.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida said that claims about the 2020 election being stolen were false, directly contradicting a central argument of former President Donald J. Trump and his supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a stereotype-defying shape-shifter, superpowered shelter pets and the newest “Guardians of the Galaxy” adventure.
content: Nimona is a shape-shifter, a monster, a misunderstood hellion with a heart of gold. Voiced by Chloë Grace Moretz, the title character busts into a futuristic world where knights defend the castle and the powerful might not be as benevolent as they’d like the citizens to believe. Based on a best-selling graphic novel by ND Stevenson and directed by Nick Bruno and Troy Quane (who also co-directed “Spies in Disguise”), this 2023 animated feature from Netflix gives young children a mile-a-minute main character who slides between “good guy” and “bad guy” status, defying the usual stereotypes. Stevenson has called the story a transgender allegory, and the L.G.B.T.Q. representation is a welcome change from the usual kids’ movie universes, where knights fall in love with princesses, not with each other. Here, Riz Ahmed voices Ballister Boldheart, a knight who has been wrongly accused of murdering Queen Valerin (Lorraine Toussaint). Ballister reluctantly allows Nimona to help him take down a corrupt system, prove his innocence and reunite with his partner, Ambrosius Goldenloin (Eugene Lee Yang). As a character, Nimona has zero chill and might prove a little tough for adults to watch for any length of time, but my son was entertained by the character’s constant motion, chaotic energy and what-will-come-next transformations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy and Johnny Diaz
title: 4,000 Rescued Beagles, Bred for Research, Found Homes and Best Friends
description: The dogs, held in cages at a breeding and research facility, were bound for labs. About 4,000 were saved and, almost a year later, many are thriving with their families.
content: When a 2-year-old beagle named Fin was carried out in September from the Envigo breeding and research facility in Cumberland, Va., his exit marked the end of a nearly 60-day operation to rescue almost 4,000 dogs that had been living in highly distressful conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Wesley Parnell
title: Dancer Stabbed to Death Was a Shy Boy Turned Proud, Exuberant Man
description: O’Shae Sibley was determined to succeed in New York, where he had joined a community of artists and performers who pushed him to strive.
content: Karen Pendergrass kept seeing the lanky boy walk by the lunchroom where she taught dance twice a week to eighth grade students in North Philadelphia. He would peer inside, then run away as soon as Ms. Pendergrass made eye contact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Is Expected to Permanently Block Grand Canyon Mining
description: The president is likely to create a new national monument that would ban uranium mining on a million acres around the canyon, something Native tribes have sought for decades.
content: President Biden is likely to announce the creation of a new national monument to protect about a million acres of land around the Grand Canyon from uranium mining as soon as next week, according to three people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: What to Know About the Opera Star David Daniels’s Sexual Assault Trial
description: The countertenor and his husband, Scott Walters, each face a charge of aggravated sexual assault in Texas.
content: Update: Just as the trial was set to begin on Friday, David Daniels and his husband, Scott Walters, pleaded guilty to sexual assault of an adult, a second-degree felony, after reaching a deal that will spare them jail time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Critical Election Republicans Are Hoping You Won’t Notice
description: Abortion opponents in Ohio are counting on low turnout next Tuesday.
content: There’s an extraordinarily important referendum in Ohio next week that the anti-abortion movement hopes most citizens don’t notice. It’s a vote that demonstrates why reproductive rights and the preservation of democracy, two issues that have catalyzed recent Democratic victories, are intertwined. That’s almost certainly why it’s being held in the torpid month of August, a time when a great many people would rather think about almost anything other than politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: It’s August Already: Are You Making the Most of Your Patio or Terrace?
description: Designers Christine and John Gachot should know how to furnish an outdoor space: Their rental has six. Here’s their step-by-step guide.
content: It’s hard to beat summer in the city — except maybe on the very hottest days. And if you’re lucky enough to have a little outdoor space, like a balcony, terrace or patio, it’s even better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: NASA Reaches Voyager 2 With a Last-Ditch ‘Shout’ Across the Void
description: After an erroneous command sent the spacecraft’s antenna askew, mission specialists hatched a plan to point it back toward Earth.
content: It took an interstellar “shout” across the solar system. But NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory said on Friday that it re-established full communications with Voyager 2, an aging probe exploring the outer edges of the solar system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell
title: Shares of Carl Icahn’s Firm Tank After It Cuts Dividend
description: Bowing to pressure from a short seller, Mr. Icahn halved his company’s quarterly dividend and said he would return to the style of investing that made him famous.
content: Shares of Icahn Enterprises, the firm led by the billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn, fell as much as 30 percent on Friday after the saber-rattling investor, under pressure from a short seller, said his firm would halve its quarterly dividend and refocus on the style of activist investing that brought him his fame and fortune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Is a U.S. Debt Crisis Looming? Is it Even Possible?
description: A disaster story that sounds plausible until you think hard about it
content: On Tuesday, Fitch, one of the Big Three credit rating agencies, startled many observers by downgrading U.S. debt. Biden administration officials weren’t the only people who were shocked and angry; quite a few economists, including some who had warned strongly against big spending, pronounced the decision “inept,” “bizarre,” “absurd” and worse. Indeed, it was hard to think of any way in which the U.S. fiscal outlook had deteriorated since last year, when Fitch gave us a clean bill of health.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A (Sad) Playlist for the 2023 New York Mets
description: Fifteen songs that tell the tale of a rough season.
content: This week, there has been joy neither in Mudville nor in Queens — home of the New York Mets, a team enjoying a catastrophically disappointing 2023 season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: It’s OK to Be a Summer Grinch
description: You might be hot, sweaty and tired. But there are things you can do to manage.
content: On some summer days, I prefer to lurk, like a mushroom, in a dank corner of my house — and not just to escape the record heat. I don’t want to glance outside and be reminded that I should be barbecuing somewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Does It Matter What Trump Really Believes?
description: Readers discuss the latest indictment of the former president. Also: Anti-Trump Republicans; racial disparities in the pool; multitasking; dog behavior.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Recipes That Meet You Where You Are
description: Chilaquiles verdes for when you want to get lost in your kitchen, and kimchi carbonara for when you don’t.
content: Good morning. I came down with Covid for the second time last week, and it left me shivering, sweating, panting a little, unable to sleep, unable to get out of bed. I watched things on my screens. I drank a lot of Gatorade and swallowed my dose of Paxlovid in the mornings and at night. I ate little. I kept panic about my breathlessness at bay. It was not a good time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Everybody Dance Now! ‘Here Lies Love’ Dictates Your Moves.
description: Engaging viewers’ bodies is central to this Broadway musical, a rare production that sets its audience in motion on the dance floor.
content: Like many Broadway musicals, “Here Lies Love” involves a lot of dancing. Notably less common: how much moving is done by the audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu and Paul Mozur
title: Why TSMC Will Keep Its Roots in Taiwan, Even as It Goes Global
description: In an interview, the chip maker’s chairman, Mark Liu, explained why TSMC’s top tech would stay in Taiwan, despite growing threats from China and worries from the United States.
content: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, which is manufacturing the world’s most advanced microchips, conducts business on the island of Taiwan, dead center in one of the most geopolitically volatile places on the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: ‘You Have to Work Extra to Hire People’: What Companies Have Been Saying About Jobs
description: Some executives said they were not expanding their payrolls as quickly as they had, while others were more concerned about wage growth, which has remained robust.
content: As companies reported their latest quarterly earnings in recent weeks, hiring, wages and head counts were popular topics as analysts quizzed executives about their plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Niger’s Coup Leaders Sever Ties With France, as Detained President Pleads for Help
description: The military junta that ousted the president in the West African nation of Niger last week also dismissed Niger’s ambassadors to key partners: the United States, France and Nigeria.
content: Niger’s coup leaders on Thursday said that they had severed military ties with France, their country’s former colonial ruler, throwing into uncertainty the future of 1,500 French troops based there, in a region of West Africa plagued with coups and Islamist insurgencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Correa
title: Simone Biles Set to Compete for First Time Since Tokyo Olympics
description: Biles, the decorated American gymnast, is making her return to elite competition on Saturday at the U.S. Classic. The field also includes Sunisa Lee, the reigning Olympic all-around champion.
content: Simone Biles, who over the past decade has revolutionized what is possible in gymnastics, is set to compete Saturday for the first time since 2021, when she won two medals at the Tokyo Olympics but also withdrew from five events to protect her mental and physical health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Rush
title: What Our Beech Tree Teaches Us About the Possibility of the Future
description: The idea of a “new normal” steals from us the possibility of being transformed, for better or worse.
content: A few falls ago, a friend forwarded us a real estate listing. Though we were not really in the market, we looked. The big orange bungalow was nice, but it was the beech tree that cast a spell. The enormous trunk looked like the leg of an old elephant. On the day we toured the house, thousands of hard, spiny burrs enclosing beech nuts blanketed the side yard. That, we were told, was a mast year, the beech seeding in exceptional quantities — which, of course, I took as a sign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Man Charged in California Stabbings Found Not Competent for Trial
description: A judge concluded that the former University of California, Davis, student was mentally ill and must receive treatment before a legal case could proceed.
content: A Northern California judge has ruled that a former college student is not mentally competent to stand trial for a series of stabbings that killed two people and terrorized the community around the University of California, Davis, this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: How the ‘Spider-Verse’ Movies Have Changed Animation for the Better
description: The new Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie and other C.G.I. cartoons are taking a looser, imperfect approach. The style represents a shift made possible by Spidey’s success.
content: When “TMNT,” a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles animated film, was released in 2007, the critic Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in The New York Times that it offered “an impressive lack of visual texture.” She was not wrong. The eponymous reptiles are rendered in an inert computer-generated form, as if they were modeled from plastic and then put on a screen. Their green skin is dull and smooth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: How Jack Smith Structured the Trump Election Indictment to Reduce Risks
description: The special counsel layered varied charges atop the same facts, while sidestepping a free-speech question by not charging incitement.
content: In accusing former President Donald J. Trump of conspiring to subvert American democracy, the special counsel, Jack Smith, charged the same story three different ways. The charges are novel applications of criminal laws to unprecedented circumstances, heightening legal risks, but Mr. Smith’s tactic gives him multiple paths in obtaining and upholding a guilty verdict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: What to Know About Novorossiysk, the Russian Port Attacked by Ukraine
description: The seaport is one of Russia’s largest by volume and among the biggest in Europe, crucial to the export of Russian grain, oil, and other products to countries around the world.
content: The Ukrainian drone attack on Friday on a Russian warship in Novorossiysk, Russia, served as another blow for the Russian Navy, which operates a base in the Black Sea port city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Anger Builds in Towns Deliberately Flooded, in Part, to Save Beijing
description: A provincial leader set off an outcry by urging cities to serve as a “moat” for the capital, as diverted floodwaters sent scores of residents fleeing.
content: For days, the rain came down in sheets, pounding Beijing and areas around it in what the government said was the heaviest deluge China’s capital had seen since record keeping began 140 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: How Sure of Love? 100 Percent, and Then Some.
description: Anne Huntington was producing a podcast about dating — all while avoiding commitment. Tyler DePatis, on the other hand, was “110 percent” sure about her.
content: On their first date, Anne Stewart Huntington and Tyler Paul DePatis broke their own rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Some of the Things You’ll Be Paying More For
description: Gas and electric bills are going up, and so are bridge and tunnel tolls, not to mention subway fares.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at why your electric and gas bill went up if you are a Con Edison customer, and why tolls for some bridges and tunnels will go up starting Sunday. We’ll also look at two investigations of people who are, or were, close to Mayor Eric Adams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Siyi Zhao
title: China Wants Children to Spend Less Time on Their Smartphones
description: A proposal from the country’s internet regulator would require app developers and device makers to adopt a “minor mode” to limit screen time and content for young people.
content: A few years ago, China cracked down on video games. Then it imposed limits on livestreaming by children. Now China wants them to spend less time on their smartphones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Inside U.S. Team, a Campaign to Avert Disaster Gets Personal
description: Blocking out criticism they call “noise,” Lindsey Horan and other veterans are taking a one-on-one approach to turning around their World Cup fortunes.
content: In the days since the United States team narrowly avoided an embarrassing early elimination from the Women’s World Cup, Lindsey Horan, its co-captain, has been working the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: Donald Trump’s day in court.
content: In a Washington courthouse, Donald Trump pleaded not guilty to charges that he had conspired to remain in office despite his 2020 election loss. Asked for his plea to the four counts he faces, the former president replied, “Not guilty.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Honoring O’Shae Sibley at the Stonewall Inn
description: “He was just a beautiful spirit, a wonderful person, just exercising his freedom to be alive.”
content: On Thursday evening, 80 mourners gathered at the Stonewall Inn, a New York City bar known for its pivotal role in the gay rights movement, to honor O’Shae Sibley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: 130 Degrees and Rising: How Kitchen Workers Are Dealing With Record Heat
description: With punishing temperatures across many states, restaurants are adapting to a new climate reality.
content: Around midday on Wednesday, as the heat index reached more than 102 degrees in Baton Rouge, La., Tremaine Devine was searing burgers on the grill inside his food truck when he began to turn pale and felt lightheaded and short of breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Jess Search, a Force in the Documentary Genre, Dies at 54
description: As one of the leaders of Doc Society, she supported countless filmmakers, with an emphasis on underrepresented groups and unconventional stories.
content: Jess Search, a producer on dozens of important documentaries and a catalyst on many more as one of the directors of Doc Society, a nonprofit organization she helped found in 2005 that supports documentary filmmakers, died on July 31 in London. She was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Incorvaia
title: New Antarctic Starfish Are Doting Parents and Vicious Predators
description: A close examination of a collection of starfish in the Smithsonian revealed even more starfish inside those starfish.
content: Christopher Mah, a biologist at the Smithsonian, was scouring the shelves of the museum for deep-sea starfish when he had an idea: Why not see if any of the specimens were preserved with their last meal still digesting inside of them, to help understand their natural diet?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Chris Christie Meets With Ukrainian President in Surprise Trip to Kyiv
description: Mr. Christie is the second 2024 G.O.P. hopeful to visit the war-torn nation, signaling his support for Ukraine in its effort to repel Russia.
content: Former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey made an unannounced visit to Ukraine on Friday to meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky, offering full-throated support for the nation in its war with Russia while staking out a clear position on an issue that has divided his party and his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: At the World Cup, the Field Thins and the Contenders Expand
description: After 48 games, half of the teams have been sent home. And yet it feels as if the field of potential winners is bigger than it was at the start.
content: There are a few things that can be known for certain. Canada, the Olympic champion, will not add a Women’s World Cup to its list of honors this year. Marta, the Brazilian star, will not end her career with the one international trophy that has eluded her. And Germany, somehow, managed to engineer its own exit despite winning its first game by six goals. Three superpowers, from three continents, are out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wolff
title: Down the Rabbit Hole Into Donald Trump’s Brain
description: Can prosecutors convince a jury Trump means every bonkers thing he says?
content: Not long after Mark Meadows, Donald Trump’s last chief of staff, left the White House, I asked him about the rambling telephone call he had participated in during which Mr. Trump told Brad Raffensperger, the Georgia secretary of state, to find him enough votes to overcome Joe Biden’s lead in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Appeals Court Overturns Mississippi’s Lifetime Ban on Voting for Former Felons
description: A federal appeals court said that barring people convicted of certain felonies from voting pointlessly denied them access to “the democratic core of American citizenship.”
content: Mississippi’s lifetime ban on voting for people convicted of a range of felonies is cruel and unusual punishment that violates the Eighth Amendment and “is at odds with society’s evolving standards of decency,” a federal appeals court ruled on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: New Florida Immigration Rules Start to Strain Some Businesses
description: Some employers said they were losing workers because of the new law, which was championed by Gov. Ron DeSantis.
content: After signing into law a raft of new measures aimed at undocumented immigrants in Florida, Gov. Ron DeSantis said the legislation gave the state “the most ambitious anti-illegal immigration laws in the country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Lefton
title: Japan’s Enduring ‘Sound of Summer’
description: Created 75 years ago for the country’s prestigious high school baseball tournament, Yuji Koseki’s “The Crown Will Shine on You” stirs memories as it inspires new ones.
content: In addition to being a starting pitcher for the Toronto Blue Jays, Yusei Kikuchi is an accomplished karaoke crooner who is proud of his spirited version of the fight song of his former team in Japan, the Seibu Lions. When he was asked during an off day between starts if he knew the words of a more popular song, “Eikan ha Kimi ni Kagayaku,” or “The Crown Will Shine on You,” the competitor in him took over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: The Risks Hidden in Public Pension Funds
description: Attracted by promises of high returns, many public pension funds have been loading up on private equity but may not fully appreciate the dangers, our columnist says.
content: The Oregon Public Employees Retirement Fund prides itself on being open about its investments, publishing monthly reports that provide more timely information than most other state and local government pension plans across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: eclectic
description: This word has appeared in 306 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word eclectic has appeared in 306 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 4 in “Her Symphony Reclaims an Ancestral Story, and Classical Music” by Tim Greiving:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: The Recovery Left Nevada Behind. Can the State Change Its Luck?
description: Nevada has the highest unemployment rate in the country at 5.4 percent as officials insist the economy must move away from its focus on gambling.
content: Pedro Alvarez never imagined his high school job delivering filet mignon and sautéed lobster tail to rooms at the Tropicana Las Vegas would turn into a longtime career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Julia Scully, Influential Photography Editor and Memoirist, Dies at 94
description: She oversaw Modern Photography for 20 years and wrote an acclaimed book about her rough-and-tumble childhood, some of it spent in an orphanage and in remote Alaska.
content: Julia Scully, who after 20 years as the editor of Modern Photography magazine wrote an acclaimed memoir about her Depression-era childhood, when her mother put her and her sister in an orphanage before moving the family into a roadhouse in a remote part of Alaska, died on July 18 at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What Happens When California Clears Its Homeless Encampments?
description: A conversation with Livia Albeck-Ripka, who recently wrote about the closure of a camp in Oakland, one of the state’s largest.
content: Over 171,000 homeless people live in California, more than in any other state in the country. For many Californians facing life without a permanent home, encampments can offer a profound sense of community to people who have little else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: The Synagogue Attack Stands Alone, but Experts Say Violent Rhetoric Is Spreading
description: At his trial, the man who killed 11 at a Pittsburgh synagogue was portrayed as a lonely man engulfed in online extremism. Experts say many people fit that description.
content: Mass shooters do not often end up on trial. Many are killed or take their own lives in their attacks, some leaving behind a manifesto explaining why they acted, others leaving a mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Things That Can Really Make Someone Pop
description: Brandon Koppy’s puzzle is a sweet treat.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Justin Porter
title: U.S. Hiring Slows, but Remains Solid
description: This weekend, make eggplant Parmesan.
content: Employers across the U.S. added 187,000 jobs in July, and the unemployment rate sank to a near record low of 3.5 percent, new data showed today. Most people who want to work can find jobs, according to the report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Conviction Reversed Over Judge’s Remark That Black Man ‘Looks Like a Criminal’
description: An appeals court called a federal judge’s comment “wholly incompatible with the fair administration of justice” and ordered a new trial.
content: A federal appeals court on Thursday overturned the sentence and the conviction of a Black man after a white federal judge in Michigan had said during a court proceeding that the man “looks like a criminal to me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Leny Andrade, ‘First Lady of Brazilian Jazz,’ Dies at 80
description: With her soulful, cigarette-tinged contralto and emotive “bossa-jazz” stylings, she mesmerized audiences and critics alike.
content: Leny Andrade, the Brazilian singer who earned an international following with her soulful fusion of samba, bossa nova and American jazz and whom Tony Bennett once called the Ella Fitzgerald of Brazil, died on July 24 in Rio de Janeiro. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Nate Schweber
title: Prosecutors Identify Human Remains Found in 2011 Near Gilgo Beach
description: The skull belonged to Karen Vergata, who had disappeared in 1996. Other parts of her body had been found on Fire Island years before.
content: A skull that was found in 2011 near Gilgo Beach on Long Island has been identified as that of a troubled 34-year-old woman who went missing in 1996 and whose family had little contact with her before she disappeared, according to the authorities and relatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aamina Khan
title: The Unlikely Run-In That Blossomed Into More
description: Dancers and musicians rarely cross paths at Juilliard, so a drag queen and a T-shirt brought Christopher Reynolds and John Hewitt together.
content: At the Juilliard School, it’s rare for someone in the dance division to cross paths with someone in the music division. But that’s exactly how Christopher Kenji Butcher Reynolds, a doctoral candidate in collaborative piano, met John Livingston Hewitt, an undergraduate student in dance, in September 2019. Mr. Reynolds was wearing a T-shirt featuring Mr. Hewitt’s favorite drag queen, Trixie Mattel, when they ran into each other at the school. Earlier that year, Mr. Reynolds had followed Mr. Hewitt on Instagram after seeing him dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Digital Replicas, a Fear of Striking Actors, Already Fill Screens
description: The technology for morphing flesh-and-blood performers into virtual avatars has been improving for years. Now it has become an issue in the actors’ strike.
content: To pack three seasons’ worth of English soccer stadiums with exasperated or exhilarated crowds, the Apple TV+ comedy “Ted Lasso” turned to dozens of background actors and powerful visual effects technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Trump Leads G.O.P. in Iowa, but His Hold Is Less Dominant
description: New polling suggests that Gov. Ron DeSantis’s efforts in Iowa have been having an effect, but that the challenge of defeating Mr. Trump there is complicated by multiple factors.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s pull among likely Republican voters is less dominant in Iowa than it is nationwide, though he still leads his nearest rival, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, in the key early state by double digits, according to a new New York Times/Siena College poll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Ex-Ohio Police Officer Indicted in Fatal Shooting of Black Man
description: The former police officer, Ricky Anderson, was indicted on charges of murder and reckless homicide in the killing of Donovan Lewis, 20, who was shot while in bed.
content: A former police officer in Columbus, Ohio, has been indicted on murder charges in the August 2022 killing of a Black man who was fatally shot in bed while the police tried to serve a felony warrant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Two $50 Million Deals in Lower Manhattan Lead the Top Sales in July
description: A West Village penthouse sold for $52 million and a SoHo penthouse for $50 million. Also, Julia Koch and Alexis Stewart found buyers for their homes.
content: The investment banker Robert Shafir earned an enviable rate of return last month on the sale of a penthouse at 150 Charles Street, a brick-and-glass condominium in the West Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: How to Find Wedding Vendors That Celebrate Inclusion
description: For many couples, working with businesses that share their values and support people from diverse backgrounds is an important part of the planning process.
content: Jove Meyer didn’t think he would become an activist when he started his career as a wedding planner 15 years ago. But in 2012, while he was at a church in New York for a wedding he had planned, the pastor approached him a few minutes before the ceremony and told him, “You’re not welcome here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Inside Trump’s Washington Arraignment, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pee-wee Herman’s Commitment to Silliness and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: ‘It’s Crazy’: The Scramble for Ancient Treasures After Ukraine’s Dam Disaster
description: After the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists.
content: One summer evening as the sun sank behind the Dnipro River, the mammoth waterway that bisects Ukraine, Anatolii Volkov walked along a river beach, head down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Young Catholics Come Together, if Not Their Views
description: As young Catholics gathered from around the world in Portugal, their desires for the future of the church were as varied as the countries they came from.
content: The group of teenage pilgrims traipsing through Lisbon during this week’s big meeting of Catholic youth from all over the world seemed to have taken to heart Pope Francis’ call for them to shake things up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Nico Grant
title: Judge Narrows Scope of Coming Trial Over Google Monopoly Claims
description: The ruling did not affect some central parts of the antitrust cases about Google search, which are scheduled to go to trial next month.
content: A federal judge said this week that the Justice Department and a group of states could not move forward with some claims in antitrust complaints against Google, narrowing the scope of what is set to be the most significant federal monopoly trial against a tech giant in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Officers Hold Family at Gunpoint After License Plate Mix-Up
description: A family was headed to a youth basketball tournament when they were stopped in Frisco, Texas, after officers made a typo while running their plates. The department later apologized.
content: Demetria Heard was driving with her family from their home in Arkansas to a youth basketball tournament in the Dallas area on July 23 when she noticed that a police officer had been following her for several minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: ‘Oppenheimer’ and the Shadow of Stalin
description: What the film doesn’t say about the sources of anti-communism.
content: With its depth of historical re-creation, its cast of famous figures given tantalizingly brief appearances, its scientific, political and sociological threads running away in multiple directions, a movie like Christopher Nolan’s “Oppenheimer” doubles as an encouragement to read more deeply into the history it portrays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Jet Lag: Get Back in the Rhythm
description: Insomnia, drowsiness and brain fog can all take some of the fun out of your first few days in a faraway place. You can’t avoid jet lag, but you can follow some tips to bounce back faster.
content: You finally made it to Paris, but instead of running up the Eiffel Tower, you’re passing out in your soufflé. Blame jet lag, when your body’s circadian rhythm — its expected sleep and wake times — is out of sync with your new location, leaving you with brain fog at midday or insomnia in the wee hours. Not everyone has the same body clock, of course, and no two trips are exactly the same, but there are some tricks that could help you get your zip back quicker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Kelly
title: How QAnon and Jan. 6 Ripped the Conspiracy Theory World Apart
description: The internet-native theory and the riot it helped spawn have left even Sept. 11 truthers and those who believe in U.F.O. cover-ups deeply unsettled about the future of conspiracy culture.
content: The date was Jan. 20, 2021, and Stephen Miles Lewis was trying to keep the peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Billionaire Parts With Group Behind Israel’s Judicial Overhaul
description: Arthur Dantchik announced that he would no longer donate money to the Kohelet Policy Forum, the brains behind the highly polarizing plan.
content: Arthur Dantchik, the American multibillionaire who provided millions to the think tank behind Israel’s highly polarizing judicial overhaul plan, announced on Friday that he would no longer donate to the organization.

author: By David French
title: I Don’t See a ‘Rogue’ Supreme Court
description: Behold the last federal bastion of the pre-Trump right.
content: If you ask folks on the left to describe the contemporary Supreme Court, you may hear one or more common words used to describe it: “rogue” or “extremist” or “illegitimate” or “broken.” But when I look at the court, I see something quite different: the last federal bastion of the pre-Trump right.
source.name: The New York Times
